Package com.esri.mo2.client.sde

Implementation of the Content API for ArcSDE client services.

See:
          Description

Class Summary
SDE Deprecated. - the class has been deprecated, see Content API.
SdeConnection This connection provides access to the Content found in a single SDE instance that is accessed using the standard ArcSDE java api.
SdeContentProvider Implements the ConnectionProvider interface for ArcSDE databases.
SdeSource This Source provides access to the Content found in a single SDE instance that is accessed using the standard ArcSDE java api.
 

Exception Summary
SdeClientApiNotFoundException This exception is thrown if an application tries to access an SDE LayerSource, but the ArcSDE JAR is not present in the application's CLASSPATH.
SdeCovsWhereException This exception is thrown by an SDE FeatureClass if an application attempts to perform a search with a QueryFilter where-clause that exceeds the 320 character limit imposed by ArcSDE for Coverages for where-clauses.
 

Package com.esri.mo2.client.sde Description

Implementation of the Content API for ArcSDE client services.

Applications can connect to ArcSDE layer objects and access them as either a com.esri.mo2.data.feat.FeatureDataset, a com.esri.mo2.data.feat.FeatureClass, or a com.esri.mo2.map.dpy.FeatureLayer. Applications can also connect to ArcSDE tables and access them as com.esri.mo2.data.feat.Table.

A typical sequence for accessing ArcSDE Content is like this:

   Connection connection = new SdeConnection(server,instance,database,username,password);
   Source source = SourceCache.getSource(connection);
   source.connect();
   Content content = source.getContent("path to content");

   ...<>...

   source.disconnect();
Content paths have the following form for ArcSDE objects: 
    /SdeLayer{/FeatureType}, or
    /SdeTable
"SdeLayer" and "SdeTable" are the fully qualified names of the ArcSDE layer or table, respectively.

Specifying only the "SdeLayer" name will produce a Folder representing the specified ArcSDE layer. To obtain a FeatureClass of the data inside an SDE layer, the getContents method can be used to return the set of Content objects available in the Folder. Each of these Content objects represents a single FeatureClass in the SDE layer. From this Content object a FeatureClass and FeatureLayer can be obtained by using the getData method.

Specifying "SdeLayer" name followed by the name of a feature type directly obtains the Content representing a particular FeatureClass, without having to first obtain the Folder. This would be useful when the feature type is known in advance. Valid feature types are listed within the Cat.properties ResourceBundle within the MapObjects resource JAR. These are "Point", "Polyline", and "Polygon".

Specifying "SdeTable" name will produce a Content representing the specified SDE table. Use the getData method to obtain a Table object from which the data can be accessed.

For example, suppose you have an ArcSDE database that contains two ArcSDE Layers named "Fred" and "Bloggs". Fred has Point features only, but Bloggs has both Points and Polylines. The path to access Fred point features is "Fred/Point", and the path to access Bloggs lines is "Bloggs/Polyline".

The simplest way to ensure that the correct path is used to access a particular content is to view the path to the content shown in the Catalog component - for instance, when used within the JoView Plus sample application.

Support for accessing ArcSDE feature layers, feature classes, and tables is implemented using the ArcSDE Java client API that is provided in a separate JAR (currently, jsde83_sdk.jar and jsde83_sdkres.jar). If you try to open an SDE Source and the ArcSDE Java client api JAR is not currently available in the application CLASSPATH, an Exception will be thrown.

The diagram in the com.esri.mo2.src.sys package shows public classes of the com.esri.mo2.client.sde package and their relations with other interfaces and classes of the MapObjects--Java framework.
